iso4217:EUR xbrli:shares xbrli:pure iso4217:USD 3246000 8722000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;</font><font style="display: inline;">Act</font><font style="display: inline;">ivity within our accumulated other comprehensive income (&#x201C;AOCI&#x201D;) balance consists solely of gains and losses resulting from the translation of foreign subsidiary financial statements to our reporting currency. Foreign currency translation resulting in changes to other comprehensive income and related reclassification adjustments are presented net of tax effects on the consolidated statements of other comprehensive income. Foreign currency reclassification adjustments are included within the line item entitled &#x2018;Foreign currency transaction gains (losses), net&#x2019; on the consolidated statements of operations.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 198000000 990 4642000 5607000 3680000 11828000 3441000 9874000 3656000 6857000 13315000 10513000 <div> <div 4100000 4300000 2013 2013 2013 2013 2013 2013 2010 2007 2009 2007 2007 2007 109100000 140455000 5700000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">15. LEGAL PROCEEDINGS</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">We and certain current and former officers and directors have been named as defendants in complaints filed by investors in the United States District Court for the District of Colorado. The first complaint was filed in November&nbsp;2007 and several other complaints were filed shortly thereafter. These actions were consolidated and, in September&nbsp;2008, the district court appointed a lead plaintiff and counsel. An amended consolidated complaint was filed in December&nbsp;2008. The amended complaint purports to state claims under Section&nbsp;10(b), 20(a), and 20A of the Exchange Act on behalf of a class of all persons who purchased our common stock between April&nbsp;2, 2007 and April&nbsp;14, 2008 (the &#x201C;Class&nbsp;Period&#x201D;). The amended complaint also added our independent auditor as a defendant. The amended complaint alleges that, during the Class&nbsp;Period, the defendants made false and misleading public statements about us and our business and prospects and, as a result, the market price of our common stock was artificially inflated. The amended complaint also claims that certain current and former officers and directors traded in our common stock on the basis of material non-public information. The amended complaint seeks compensatory damages on behalf of the alleged class in an unspecified amount, including interest, and also added attorneys&#x2019; fees and costs of litigation. On February&nbsp;28, 2011, the District Court granted motions to dismiss filed by the defendants and dismissed all claims. A final judgment was thereafter entered. Plaintiffs subsequently appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit.&nbsp; We and those current and former officers and directors named as defendants have entered into a Stipulation of Settlement with the plaintiffs that would, if approved by the United States District Court for the District of Colorado, resolve all claims asserted against us by the plaintiffs on behalf of the putative class, and plaintiffs&#x2019; appeal would be dismissed. Our independent auditor is not a party to the Stipulation of Settlement. The Stipulation of Settlement received preliminary approval from the District Court on August&nbsp;28, 2013.&nbsp; It remains subject to customary conditions, including final court approval following notice to stockholders. On February 13, 2014 a final settlement hearing took place and the parties are awaiting a ruling in conjunction with the same.&nbsp;&nbsp;If the settlement becomes final, all amounts required by the settlement will be paid by our insurers. There can be no assurance that the settlement will be finally approved by the District Court, or that approval by the District Court will, if challenged, be upheld by the Tenth Circuit. </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">On October&nbsp;27, 2010, Spectrum Agencies (&#x201C;Spectrum&#x201D;) filed suit against our subsidiary, Crocs Europe B.V. (&#x201C;Crocs Europe&#x201D;), in the High Court of Justice, Queen&#x2019;s Bench Division, Royal Courts of Justice in London, United Kingdom (&#x201C;UK&#x201D;). Spectrum acted as an agent for Crocs products in the UK from 2005 until Crocs Europe terminated the relationship on July&nbsp;3, 2008 due to Spectrum&#x2019;s breach of its duty to act in good faith towards Crocs Europe. Spectrum alleges that Crocs Europe unlawfully terminated the agency relationship and failed to pay certain sales commissions. A trial on the liability, not quantum (compensation and damages), was held at the High Court in London from November&nbsp;30, 2011 to December&nbsp;5, 2011. On December&nbsp;16, 2011, the High Court of Justice issued a judgment that found that although Spectrum&#x2019;s actions were a breach of its duty to act in good faith towards Crocs Europe the breach was not sufficiently severe to justify termination. We believe that the trial judge erred in his findings and subsequently appealed the judgment.&nbsp; On October&nbsp;30, 2012, the Court of Appeal handed down its judgment confirming the trial judge&#x2019;s findings. We submitted a request to the Supreme Court seeking permission to appeal.&nbsp; On April&nbsp;24, 2013 the Supreme Court declined to grant permission to appeal.&nbsp; Given that to date the legal proceedings in this case have only addressed liability, there have been no findings in relation to the amount of compensation or damages other than with respect to legal fees. Under English law, the prevailing party is entitled to reimbursement of reasonable legal fees incurred in the proceedings. The trial of&nbsp;liability and quantum were split by the&nbsp;Court&nbsp;in the interests of case management. The&nbsp;alleged quantum of damages&nbsp;has not been&nbsp;fully&nbsp;pleaded out and will be assessed as part of the forthcoming damages phase.&nbsp; A trial and judgment on dama</font><font style="display: inline;">ges is expected in approximately 12</font><font style="display: inline;"> months.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">We are currently subject to an audit by U.S. Customs&nbsp;&amp; Border Protection (&#x201C;CBP&#x201D;) in respect of the period from 2006 to 2010.&nbsp; In the course of the audit, we identified certain valuation errors and tendered ap</font><font style="display: inline;">proximately </font><font style="display: inline;">$1.4</font><font style="display: inline;"> million in additional duties. Subsequently, we identified additional value errors which will require the payment of additional duties totaling approximately </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.7</font><font style="display: inline;"> million. The exact amount of this additional tender is subject to verification by CBP.&nbsp;&nbsp;In October&nbsp;2013, CBP issued an audit report to which we filed comments and objections.&nbsp; CBP has projected unpaid duties totaling approximately </font><font style="display: inline;">$12.4</font><font style="display: inline;"> million in connec</font><font style="display: inline;">tion with various classification errors during the period under review.&nbsp; We have responded that these projections are erroneous and provided arguments that demonstrate the amount due in connection with this matter is considerably less than the amount projected.&nbsp; CBP is currently reviewing this response.&nbsp; It is not possible at this time to predict whether our arguments will be successful in eliminating or reducing the amount in dispute.&nbsp; At this time, it is not possible to determine when a formal notice of claim will be received from CBP</font><font style="display: inline;">. &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">Likewise, it is not possible to predict whether CBP may seek to assert a claim for penalties in addition to any unpaid duties. </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Mexico&#x2019;s Federal Tax Authority (&#x201C;SAT&#x201D;) audited the period from January&nbsp;2006 to July&nbsp;2011.&nbsp; There were two phases to the audit, the first for capital equipment and finished goods and the second for raw materials.&nbsp; The first phase was completed and no major discrepancies were noted by the SAT.&nbsp; On January&nbsp;9, 2013, Crocs received a notice for the second phase in which the SAT issued a tax assessment (taxes and penalties) of roughl</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">y &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">280.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million pesos (approximately </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$22.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million) based on the value of all of Crocs&#x2019; imported raw materials during the audit period.&nbsp; We believe that the proposed penalty amount is unfounded and without merit. With the help of local counsel we filed an appeal by the deadline of March&nbsp;15, 2013.&nbsp; We have argued that the amount due in connection with the matter, if any, is substantially less than that proposed by the SAT.&nbsp; In connection with the appeal, the SAT required us to post an appeal surety bond in the amount of roughly </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">321.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million pesos (approximately </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$26.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million), which</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> amount reflects estimated additional penalties and interest if we are not successful on our appeal.&nbsp; This amount will be adjusted on an annual basis. We are currently awaiting a ruling from the Mexican courts.&nbsp; It is not possible at this time to predict the outcome of this matter or reasonably estimate any potential loss.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">As of December 31, 2013, we have accrued a total </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$11.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">8</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million relatin</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">g to these litigation matters and other disputes. We estimate that the ultimate resolution of these litigation matters and other disputes could result in a loss that is reasonably possible betwee</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">n &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> and </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$10.6</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million in th</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">e aggregate, in excess of the amount accrued.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Although we are subject to other litigation from time to time in the ordinary course of business, including employment, intellectual property and product liability claims, we are not party to any other pending legal proceedings that we believe will have a material adverse impact on our business, financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 3067000 3811000 20000000 3500000 4800000 6100000 23255000 24517000 1300000 1100000 500000 0.032 0.046 0.034 40300000 1100000 12400000 5900000 3500000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p><p style="page-break-after:always">&nbsp;</p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;;font-size: 10pt"><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;"></font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Recently Issued Accounting Pronouncements</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">In July&nbsp;2013, the FASB issued ASU No.&nbsp;2013-11</font><font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;"> Income Taxes (Topic 740): Presentation of an Unrecognized Tax Benefit when a Net Operating Loss Carryforward, a Similar Tax Loss, or a Tax Credit Carryforward Exists</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> (&#x201C;ASU No.&nbsp;2013-11&#x201D;). This pronouncement provides guidance on financial statement presentation of an unrecognized tax benefit (&#x201C;UTB&#x201D;) when a net operating loss (&#x201C;NOL&#x201D;) carryforward, a similar tax loss or a tax credit carryforward exists. Under the pronouncement, an entity must present a UTB, or a portion of the UTB, in the financial statements as a reduction to a deferred tax asset (&#x201C;DTA&#x201D;) for an NOL carryforward, a similar tax loss or a tax credit carryforward except when:</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:18pt;"><p style="width:18pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;;"> 1)</font> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">An NOL carryforward, a similar tax loss or a tax credit carryforward is not available as of the reporting date under the governing tax law to settle that would result from the disallowance of the tax position.</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <div style="width:100%"><table style="width:100%;" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"><tr><td style="width:18pt;"><p style="width:18pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td valign="top" align="left" style="width: 18.00pt; display: inline;"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10pt;;"> 2)</font> </p> </td><td style="width:0pt;"><p style="width:0pt;width:0pt;font-size:0pt;"></p></td><td align="left" valign="top"> <p style="border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt;margin:0pt;"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The entity does not intend to use the DTA for this purpose (provided that the tax law permits a choice).</font></p></td></tr></table></div> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">If either of these conditions exists, an entity should present a UTB in the financial statements as a liability and should not net the UTB with a DTA. This amendment does not affect the amounts disclosed in the tabular reconciliation of the total amounts of UTBs because the tabular reconciliation presents gross amounts of UTBs. This pronouncement is effective for fiscal years and interim periods within those fiscal years beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2013. The Company will adopt the provisions of ASU No.&nbsp;2013-11 on January&nbsp;1, 2014. We do not anticipate the provisions of</font><font style="display: inline;"> ASU No.&nbsp;2013-11 will</font><font style="display: inline;"> have a material impact on to the Company&#x2019;s consolidated </font><font style="display: inline;">financial position or results of operations.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 658000 -299000 317704000 90625000 13160000 -22000 22000 30000 -16000 16000 579000 3744000 2405000 7065000 1715000 16905000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <div style="width:100%"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" align="center" style="border-collapse:collapse;width: 75.00%;margin-left:0pt;"> <tr> <td valign="bottom" style="width:215.00pt;padding:0pt 4.3pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 1pt;border-bottom:1pt solid #000000 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 8pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:8pt;">Intangible Asset Class</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:8pt;">($ thousands)</font></p> </td> <td valign="middle" style="width:02.72%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 style="display: inline;">$</font></p> </td> <td valign="bottom" style="width:12.98%;border-top:1pt solid #000000 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:2pt double #000000 ;border-right:1pt none style="border-bottom-style:solid;width:47%;height:.85pt; ;color:#000000" align="left"></hr> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;text-indent: -18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:-18pt; padding-right:27pt;"><font style="display: inline;font-size:5pt;top:-4pt;position:relative;line-height:100%">(1</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:5pt;top:-4pt;position:relative;line-height:100%">)</font></font><font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:0pt; padding-right:4pt;text-align:left"><font style="display: inline;font-size:3pt;"></font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">A &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">corresponding entrusted loan receivable of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">$7.9</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;"> million is recorded in &#x2018;Other receivables&#x2019; as of December 31, 2012</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">as amounts are related to our subsidiaries in China. The entrusted loan was paid in full during the second quarter of 2013 and as such, the entrusted loan payable, a</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">nd corresponding receivable, were</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;"> removed from the consolidated balance sheets as of December 31, 2013.</font></font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;text-indent: -18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:-18pt; padding-right:27pt;"><font style="display: inline;font-size:5pt;top:-4pt;position:relative;line-height:100%">(2</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:5pt;top:-4pt;position:relative;line-height:100%">)</font></font><font style="text-indent:0pt;margin-left:0pt; padding-right:4pt;text-align:left"><font style="display: inline;font-size:3pt;"></font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">The amounts in Other consist of various accrued expenses and </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">no</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;"> individual item accounted for more than </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;">5%</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:9pt;"> of the total balance at December 31, 2013 or December 31, 2012.</font></font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Asset Retirement Obligations</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">We record a liability equal to the fair value of the estimated future cost to retire an asset, if the liability&#x2019;s fair value can be reasonably estimated. Our asset retirement obligation (&#x201C;ARO&#x201D;) liabilities are primarily associated with the disposal of property and equipment which we are contractually obligated to remove at the end of certain retail and office leases in order to restore the facilities back original condition as specified in the related lease agreements. We estimate the fair value of these liabilities based on current store closing costs and discount the costs back as if they were to be performed at the inception of the lease. At the inception of such leases, we record the ARO as a liability and also record a related asset in an amount equal to the estimated fair value of the obligation. The capitalized asset is then depreciated on a straight-line basis over the useful life of the asset. Upon retirement of the ARO liability, any difference between the actual retirement costs incurred and the previously recorded estimated ARO liability is recognized as a gain or loss in the consolidated statements of operations.</font><font style="display: inline;"> Our ARO liability as of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2013 and 2012</font><font style="display: inline;"> was $</font><font style="display: inline;">2.0</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">2.4</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million, respectively.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 63976000 57450000 92278000 104405000 8147000 15992000 36343000 36616000 81371000 97111000 10342000 14128000 10226000 12198000 104718000 98151000 19688000 14652000 307823000 321532000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Advertising</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Advertising costs are expensed as incurred and production costs are generally expensed when the advertising is </font><font style="display: inline;">first </font><font style="display: inline;">run. Total advertising, marketing and promotional costs reflected in &#x2018;Selling, general, and administrative expenses&#x2019; on the consolidated statement of operations were $</font><font style="display: inline;">4</font><font style="display: inline;">7.</font><font style="display: inline;">6</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, $</font><font style="display: inline;">39.8</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">39.8</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million for the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2013, 2012 and 201</font><font style="display: inline;">1</font><font style="display: inline;">, respectively.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 39800000 39800000 47600000 8600000 11300000 12500000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 14pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">10. ALLOWANCES</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The changes in the allowance for doubtful accounts and reserve for sales returns and allowances for the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2013, 2012 </font><font style="display: inline;">and 201</font><font style="display: inline;">1</font><font style="display: inline;">, are as follows:</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <div Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 8928000 8928000 11764000 11764000 14483000 14483000 9800000 13600000 17200000 1100000 1400000 1000000 528000 1410000 1400000 10949000 3900000 200000 6600000 2400000 2000000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">We record a liability equal to the fair value of the estimated future cost to retire an asset, if the liability&#x2019;s fair value can be reasonably estimated. Our asset retirement obligation (&#x201C;ARO&#x201D;) liabilities are primarily associated with the disposal of property and equipment which we are contractually obligated to remove at the end of certain retail and office leases in order to restore the facilities back original condition as specified in the related lease agreements. We estimate the fair value of these liabilities based on current store closing costs and discount the costs back as if they were to be performed at the inception of the lease. At the inception of such leases, we record the ARO as a liability and also record a related asset in an amount equal to the estimated fair value of the obligation. The capitalized asset is then depreciated on a straight-line basis over the useful life of the asset. Upon retirement of the ARO liability, any difference between the actual retirement costs incurred and the previously recorded estimated ARO liability is recognized as a gain or loss in the consolidated statements of operations.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 829638000 875159000 613115000 143236000 170426000 85756000 111785000 511203000 14489000 25738000 640077000 139855000 177343000 137701000 51155000 506054000 14093000 63743000 4022000 2368000 2165000 100000 100000 145583000 257587000 294348000 317144000 112004000 36761000 22796000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Cash and Cash Equivalents</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Cash and cash equivalents represent cash and short-term, highly liquid investments with maturities of three months or less at the date of purchase. We consider receivables from credit card companies to be cash equivalents, if expected to be received within five days.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">13. COMMITMENTS AND CONTINGENCIES</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Rental Commitments and Contingencies</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">We rent space for our retail stores, offices, warehouses, vehicles, and equipment under operating leases expiring at various dates through 2033.</font><font style="display: inline;"> Certain leases contain rent escalation clauses (step rents) that require additional rental amounts in the later years of the term. Rent expense for leases with step rents or rent holidays is recognized on a straight-line basis over the lease term</font><font style="display: inline;"> beginning on the lease inception date</font><font style="display: inline;">. Deferred rent is included in the consolidated balance sheets in &#x2018;Accrued expenses and other current liabilities.&#x2019;</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Future minimum annual rental commitments under non-cancelable operating leases for each of the five succeeding years as of </font><font ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Purchase Commitments</font> </p> <p 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">As of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2013</font><font style="display: inline;">, we had purchase commitments with certain third party manufacturers for $</font><font style="display: inline;">172.3</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million</font><font style="display: inline;">. &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">As of December&nbsp;31, 2012, we had purchase commitments with certain third party manufacturers for </font><font style="display: finished product where title passes to us upon receipt.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">In February&nbsp;2011, we renewed and amended our supply agreement with Finproject&nbsp;S.r.l. which provides us the exclusive right to purchase certain raw materials used to manufacture our products. The agreement also provides that we meet minimum purchase requirements to maintain exclusivity throughout the term of the agreement, which expires December&nbsp;31, 2014. Historically, the minimum purchase requirements have not been onerous and we do not expect them to become onerous in the future. Depending on the material purchased, pricing is either based on contracted price or is subject to quarterly reviews and fluctuates based on order volume, currency fluctuations and raw material prices. Pursuant to the agreement, we guarantee the payment for certain third party manufacturer purchases of these raw materials up to a maximum potential amount of &#x20AC;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">3.5</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;million (approximately $</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">4.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">8</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;million as of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">December 31, 2013</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">), through a letter of credit that was issued to Finproject&nbsp;S.r.l.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Government Tax Audits</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We are regularly subject to, and are currently undergoing, audits by tax authorities in the United States and </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">several </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">foreign jurisdictions for prior tax years.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 12pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">In April&nbsp;2013, the State of Sao Paulo, Brazil government (&#x201C;Brazil&#x201D;) assessed sales taxes, interest and penalties for the period April&nbsp;2009 to May&nbsp;2011.&nbsp;We had previously tendered these taxes using Brazil obligations purchased at a discount from third parties. On&nbsp;May&nbsp;22, 2013, we&nbsp;applied for amnesty in order to receive a significant reduction in penalties and interest, agreed to amend our 2009&nbsp;through&nbsp;2012&nbsp;tax returns to remove the Brazil obligations, and agreed to settle the assessment in cash to Brazil. In June&nbsp;2013, cash payment was made to Brazil, in full satisfaction of the Brazil assessment. Brazil is&nbsp;making&nbsp;court-ordered&nbsp;payments to&nbsp;holders of&nbsp;the Brazil obligations along with accrued interest.&nbsp;&nbsp; The Company anticipates that the Brazil obligations (plus accrued interest) will be paid by Brazil in accordance with the court-orders.&nbsp; The Company is carrying the Brazil obligations at the original discounted cost</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">to the Company and intends to hold the Brazil obligations until paid by Brazil. The net impact of the above is a </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$6.1</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million charge to operating income</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> recorded during the year ended December 31, 2013</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, and the carrying balance of the Br</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">azil obligations as of December 31, 2013 is </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$3.5</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">million</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, which is recorded in &#x2018;Other assets&#x2019; on the consolidated balance sheets.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The Company is currently undergoing a tax audit in Canada. We recently received a notice of proposed adjustment on certain transfer pricing&nbsp;items&nbsp;from the Canadian tax authorities, which includes penalties and interest. The proposed adjustment, along with penalties and interest, is currently being reviewed by the Canada Transfer Pricing Review Committee with a decision expected by the end </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">of the first quarter in 2014</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">. We intend to defend our position through litigation if necessary; however, the final outcome of tax audits and related litigation, including the assessment of potentially significant penalties and interest, is inherently uncertain and could be materially different than that reflected in our historical income tax provisions and accruals and could have a material adverse impact on our financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">See </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Note 15</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> &#x2013; </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Legal Proceedings for further details regarding potential loss contingencies related to government tax audits and other current legal proceedings.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 0.001 0.001 250000000 250000000 91047297 91662656 88662845 88450203 91000 92000 96757000 136210000 5384000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:9pt 0pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Basis of Consolidation</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&#x2014;The consolidated financial statements and accompanying notes have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America (&#x201C;U.S. GAAP&#x201D;). The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of our wholly-owned subsidiaries as well as variable interest entities (&#x201C;VIE&#x201D;) for which we are the primary beneficiary after the elimination of intercompany accounts and transactions. The primary beneficiary of a VIE is the entity that has (i) the power to direct the activities of the VIE that most significantly impact the VIE&#x2019;s economic performance and (ii) the obligation to absorb losses of the VIE that could potentially be significant to the VIE or the right to receive benefits from the VIE that could potentially be significant to the VIE. </font> </p> <p style="margin:9pt 0pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">In 2007, we established a relationship with Shanghai Shengyiguan Trade,&nbsp;Ltd Co (&#x201C;ST&#x201D;) for the purpose of serving as a distributor of our products in the People&#x2019;s Republic of China. We had previously determined that ST was a VIE for which we were the primary beneficiary and consequently it was consolidated as if a wholly-owned subsidiary. On March 15, 2012, we exercised an Equity Option Agreement that we had in place with ST and became the sole owner of ST.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">In April 2011, we and an unrelated third party formed Crocs Gulf, LLC (&#x201C;Crocs Gulf&#x201D;) for the purpose of selling our products in the United Arab Emirates. We have determined that Crocs Gulf is a VIE for which we are the primary beneficiary due to our variable interest in Crocs Gulf&#x2019;s equity and because we currently control all of the VIE&#x2019;s business activities and will absorb all of its expected residual returns and expected losses. All voting and dividend rights have been assigned to us. As of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2013 and 2012</font><font style="display: inline;">, the consolidated financial statements included $</font><font style="display: inline;">2.4</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">2.5</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million in total assets of Crocs Gulf, respectively, which primarily consisted of cash and cash equivalents, inventory, property and equipment. The total assets as of </font><font style="display: inline;">each of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2013</font><font style="display: inline;"> and 2012 were partially offset by $</font><font style="display: inline;">0.2</font><font style="display: inline;"> million in total liabilities, which primarily consisted of accounts payable and accrued expenses, excluding liabilities related to the support provided by us.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 8766000 16231000 464493000 515324000 569482000 2900000 4300000 6000000 11500000 4600000 2900000 4798000 -6364000 3311000 19758000 22953000 22337000 24721000 17186000 26003000 165000 597000 355000 2593000 6940000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">8. </font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">REVOLVING CREDIT FACILITY &amp; </font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">BANK BORROWINGS</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Revolving Credit Facility</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">On September 25, 2009, we entered into a Revolving Credit and Security Agreement, as amended, with the lenders named therein and PNC Bank, National Association (&#x201C;PNC&#x201D;), as a lender and administrative agent for the lenders. On December 16, 2011, we entered into our first amendment to the Revolving Credit and Security Agreement (the &#x201C;Amended and Restated Credit Agreement&#x201D;). </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">On December 27, 2013, we entered into the Third Amendment to Amended and Restated Credit Agreement (the &#x201C;Third Amendment&#x201D;), pursuant to which certain terms of the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement were amended. The Third Amendment, among other things, (i) </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">allows for the payment of dividends on the </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Series A Convertible Preferred Stock (&#x201C;Series A Preferred Stock&#x201D;)</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, (ii) pe</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">rmits the Company to have greater flexibility to repurchase its Common Stock, (iii) decreases the maximum leverage ratio from 3.50 to 1.00 to 3.25 to 1.00, and (iv) amends certain definitions of the financial covenants to become more favorable to the Company.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> See </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Note 17</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> &#x2013; </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Subsequent Events for further details regarding the payment of dividends on the Series A Preferred Stock.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The Credit Agreement enables us to borrow up to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$100.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million, with the ability to increase commitments to up to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$125.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million subject to certain conditions, and is currently set to mature on December 16, 2017. The Credit Agreement is available for working capital, capital expenditures, permitted acquisitions, reimbursement of drawings under letters of credit, and permitted dividends, distributions, purchases, redemptions and retirements of equity interests. Borrowings under the Credit Agreement are secured by all of our assets including all receivables, equipment, general intangibles, inventory, investment property, subsidiary stock and intellectual property. Borrowings under the Credit Agreement bear interest at a variable rate. For domestic rate loans, the interest rate is equal to the highest of (i)&nbsp;the daily federal funds open rate as quoted by ICAP North America, Inc. plus 0.5%, (ii)&nbsp;PNC&#x2019;s prime rate and (iii)&nbsp;a daily LIBOR rate plus 1.0%, in each case there is an additional margin ranging from 0.25% to 1.00% based on certain conditions. For LIBOR rate loans, the interest rate is equal to a LIBOR rate plus a margin ranging from 1.25% to 2.00% based on certain conditions. The Credit Agreement requires mo</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">nthly interest payments with respect to domestic rate loans and at the end of each interest period with respect to LIBOR rate loans. The Credit Agreement further provides for a limit on the issuance of letters of credit to a maximum of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$20.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million. The Credit Agreement cont</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ains provisions requiring us to maintain compliance with certain restrictive and financial covenants.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">As of December&nbsp;31, 2013 and 2012, we had </font><font style="display: inline;">no</font><font style="display: inline;"> outstanding borrowings under the Credit Agreement. As of each of December 31, 2013 and 2012, we </font><font style="display: inline;">had had issued and outstanding letters of credit of </font><font style="display: inline;">$7.2</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, which were reserved against the borrowing base under the terms of the Credit Agreement. During the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011, we capitalized </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.2</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.</font><font style="display: inline;">4</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;m</font><font style="display: inline;">illion, respectively, in fees and third party costs which were incurred in connection with the Credit Agreement, as deferred financing costs. As of December&nbsp;31, 2013, we were in compliance with all restrictive financial and other covenants under the Credit Agreement.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Long-term Bank Borrowings</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">On December 10, 2012, </font><font style="display: inline;">we </font><font style="display: inline;">entered into a Master Installment Payment Agreement (&#x201C;Master IPA&#x201D;) </font><font style="display: inline;">with PNC </font><font style="display: inline;">in which PNC finance</font><font style="display: inline;">s</font><font style="display: inline;"> the Company&#x2019;s purchase of software and services, which may include but are not limited to third party costs to design, install and implement software systems, and associated hardware described in the schedules defined within the Master IPA. This agreement was entered into to finance </font><font style="display: inline;">our</font><font style="display: inline;"> implementation of a new enterprise resource planning (&#x201C;ERP&#x201D;) system which began in October 2012 and is estimated to continue through late 2014. The terms of the agreement consist of variable interest rates and payment terms based on amounts borrowed and timing of activity throughout the implementation of the ERP</font><font style="display: inline;"> system</font><font style="display: inline;">. &nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">As of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2013 and 2012, </font><font style="display: inline;">we h</font><font style="display: inline;">ad </font><font style="display: inline;">$16.8</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and</font><font style="display: inline;"> &nbsp;$</font><font style="display: inline;">6.6</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, respectively, of long-term debt outstanding</font><font style="display: inline;"> under five and one separate notes payable</font><font style="display: inline;">, &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">respectively, </font><font style="display: inline;">of wh</font><font style="display: inline;">ich </font><font style="display: inline;">$5.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">$2.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, respectively, represent current installments</font><font style="display: inline;">. As of December 31, 2013, the notes bear interest rates ranging </font><font style="display: inline;">from </font><font style="display: inline;">2.45%</font><font style="display: inline;"> to </font><font style="display: inline;">2.79%</font><font style="display: inline;"> &nbsp;a</font><font style="display: inline;">nd maturities rangin</font><font style="display: inline;">g from </font><font style="display: inline;">September 2016</font><font style="display: inline;"> to </font><font style="display: inline;">September 2017</font><font style="display: inline;">. As this debt arrangement relates solely to the construction and implementation of an ERP system for use by the entity, all interest expe</font><font style="display: inline;">nse i</font><font style="display: inline;">ncurred under the arrangement has been capitalized to the consolidated balance sheets until the assets are ready for intended use an</font><font style="display: inline;">d will be amortized over the useful life of the software upon that date. During the year ended December 31, 2013, we capitalized </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million in interest expense related to this debt arrangement to the consolidated balance sheets. During the year ended December 31, 2012, we record</font><font style="display: inline;">ed </font><font style="display: inline;">no</font><font style="display: inline;"> capi</font><font style="display: inline;">talized interest related to this debt arrangement to the consolidated balance sheets.</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">Interest rates and payment terms are subject to changes as further financing occurs under the Master IPA.</font> 21978000 8002000 11526000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:10pt;">7. DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We transact business in various foreign countries and are therefore exposed to foreign currency exchange rate risk inherent in revenues, costs, and monetary assets and liabilities denominated in non-functional currencies. We </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">have </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">enter</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ed</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> into foreign currency exchange forward contract</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> and currency swap derivative instruments </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">to selectively protect against volatility in the value of non-functional currency denominated monetary assets and liabilities, and of future cash flows caused by changes in foreig</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">n currency exchange rates. We do not designate these</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">derivative instruments</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> as hedging instruments under the accounting standards for derivatives and hedging.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> Accordingly, these instruments are recorded at fair value as a derivative asset or liability on the balance sheet with their corresponding change in fair value recogniz</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ed in &#x2018;Foreign currency transaction (gains) losses, net&#x2019; in our</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> consolidated statements of operations. For purposes of the cash flow statement, we classify</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> the cash flows at settlement from undesignated instruments in the same category as the cash flows from the related hedged </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">items, generally with</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">in &#x2018;Cash provided by operating activities&#x2019;. Se</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">e Note 6 &#x2014; Fair Value Measurements for further details regarding the fair values of the corresponding derivative assets and liabilities.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The following table summarizes the notional amounts of the outstanding foreign cur</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">rency exchange contracts at </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">December 31, 2013 and 2012</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">. The notional amounts of the derivative financial instruments shown below are denominated in their U.S. dollar equivalents and represent the amount of all contracts of the foreign currency specified. These notional values do not necessarily represent amounts exchanged by the parties and, therefore, are not a direct measure of our exposure to the foreign currency exchange risks.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <div style="width:100%"><table style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The acco</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">unt &#x2018;Foreign currency transaction gains (losses), net&#x2019; on t</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">he </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">consolidated statements of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">operations</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> include</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> both realized and unrealized gains/losses from underlying foreign currency activity and derivative contract</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s. These gains and losses are reported on a net basis. For the year ended December 31, 2013, the n</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">et loss recognized of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$4.7</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million recorded on the consolidated statements of operations is compr</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ised of a </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$17.7</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> millio</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">n net loss associated with exposure from day-to-day business transaction</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s in various foreign currencies </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">partially offset by a</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$13</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million net gain associated with our derivative instrument</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s. F</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">or the year ended December 31</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, 2012</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, the n</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">et loss recognized of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">2.5</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million recorded on the consolidated statements of operations is compr</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ised of a </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$9.7</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> millio</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">n net loss associated with exposure from day-to-day business transaction</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s in various foreign currencies </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">partially offset by a</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">7.2</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million net gain associated with our derivative instrument</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s. F</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">or the year ended December 31</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, 2011</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, the n</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">et gain recognized of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$4.9</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">million recorded on the consolidated statements of operations is compr</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ised of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">a</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$5.4</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million net gain</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> associated with exposure from day-to-day business transaction</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s in various foreign currencies partially offset by a </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$0.5</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million net loss</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> associated with our derivative instrument</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Derivative Foreign Currency Contracts</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;We are directly and indirectly affected by fluctuations in foreign currency rates which may adversely impact our financial performance. To mitigate the potential impact of foreign currency exchange rate risk, we may employ derivative financial instruments including forward contracts and option contracts. Forward contracts are agreements to buy or sell a quantity of a currency at a predetermined future date and at a predetermined rate. An option contract is an agreement that conveys the purchaser the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell a quantity of a currency at a predetermined rate during a period or at a time in the future. These derivative financial instruments are viewed as risk management tools and are not used for trading or speculative purposes. We recognize derivative financial instruments as either assets or liabilities in the consolidated balance sheets and measure those instruments at fair value. Changes in the fair value of derivatives not designated or effective as hedges are recorded in &#x2018;Foreign currency transaction (gains)/losses, net&#x201D; in the consolidated statements of operations. We had no derivative instruments that qualified for hedge accounting during any of the periods presented. See Note&nbsp;7&#x2014;Fair Value Measurements and Financial Instruments for further discussion.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div weighted average fair value of options granted during the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2013, 2012 and 201</font><font style="display: inline;">1</font><font style="display: inline;"> was approximately $</font><font style="display: inline;">7.33</font><font style="display: inline;">, $</font><font style="display: inline;">7</font><font style="display: inline;">.76</font><font style="display: inline;"> and $</font><font style="display: inline;">9.19</font><font style="display: inline;">, respectively. The aggregate intrinsic value of options exercised during the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2013, 2012 and 201</font><font style="display: inline;">1</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">was $</font><font style="display: inline;">2.8</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, $</font><font style="display: inline;">6.9</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;milli</font><font style="display: inline;">on and $</font><font style="display: inline;">27.3</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">million, respectively. During the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2013 and 2012</font><font style="display: inline;">, we received </font><font style="display: inline;">$2.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">3.7</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million in cash in connection with the exercise of stock options with </font><font style="display: inline;">no</font><font style="display: inline;"> income tax benefit due to our use of Accounting Standard Codification 740 &#x2013; &#x2018;Income Taxes&#x2019; </font><font style="display: inline;">(with-and-without approach) </font><font style="display: inline;">(&#x201C;ASC 740&#x201D;) ordering for purposes of determining when excess benefits have been realized (see Note&nbsp;11&#x2014;Income Taxes). The</font><font style="display: inline;"> total grant date fair value of stock options vested during the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2013, 2012</font><font style="display: inline;"> and 201</font><font style="display: inline;">1</font><font style="display: inline;"> wa</font><font style="display: inline;">s $</font><font style="display: inline;">1.2</font><font style="display: inline;"> million,</font><font style="display: inline;"> &nbsp;$</font><font style="display: inline;">2.8</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million and $</font><font style="display: inline;">2.7</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million, respectively.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">As of </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 201</font><font style="display: inline;">3</font><font style="display: inline;">, we h</font><font style="display: inline;">ad $</font><font style="display: inline;">2.</font><font style="display: inline;">6</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million of t</font><font style="display: inline;">otal unrecognized share-based compensation expense related to unvested options, net of expected forfeitures, which is expected to be amortized over the remaining weighted average perio</font><font style="display: inline;">d of </font><font style="display: inline;">2.3</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;years.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Stock options under both the 2005 Plan and the 2007 Plan generally vest ratably over four years with the first year vesting on a &#x201C;cliff&#x201D; basis followed by monthly vesting for the remaining three years.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Restricted Stock </font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Awards</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;"> and Units </font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">From time to time, we grant restricted stock </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">award</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">(RSAs) </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">and restricted stock units</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> (RSUs)</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> to our employees. Unvested </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">RSAs</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> have the same rights as those of common shares including voting rights and non-forfeitable dividend rights. However, ownership of unvested </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">RSA</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">s cannot be transferred until they are vested. An unvested </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">RSU</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> is a contractual right to receive a share of common stock o</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">nly upon its vesting. RSUs have dividend equivalent rights which accrue over the term of the award and are paid if and when the RSUs vest, but they have no voting rights.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We typically grant time-based RSUs and performance-based RSUs. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Time-based RSUs are typically granted on an annual basis to certain non-executive employees and vest in </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">three</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> annual installments on a straight-line basis beginning one year after the grant date.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> During the years ende</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">d December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011, the board of directors approved grants of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">0.4</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million, </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">0.4</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">0.2</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million of RSUs to certain non-executives. Perfor</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">mance-based RSUs are typically granted on an annual basis to certain executive employees and consist of a time-based and performance-based component. The following represents the vesting schedule of performance-based RSUs granted during the years ended December 31, 2013, 2012 and 2011:</font> </p> <div style="width:100%"><table cellpadding="0" c</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ertain executives as part of a performance incentive program.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The following table summarizes RSA and RSU activity during the years ended </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, 2013, 2012</font><font style="display: inline;"> and 2</font><font style="display: inline;">011:</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <div style="width:100%"><table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;width: 100.00%;margin-left:0pt;"> <tr> <td valign="middle" style="width:31.06%;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-left:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-right:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;background-color: #auto;height:1.00pt;padding:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;height:1.00pt;overflow:hidden;font-size:0pt;"> <font style="display: </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 14pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Separation Agreements</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">On December 27, 2013, John McCarvel resigned from his position as President, Chief Executive Officer (CEO) and director of the Company effective upon the earlier to occur of (i) April 30, 2014 or (ii) the Board&#x2019;s appointment of his successor as CEO. Also on December 27, 2013, the Company and Mr. McCarvel entered into a separation agreement providing that the Company will pay Mr. McCarvel (i) a </font><font style="display: inline;">$1.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million separation payment on the first regularly scheduled payroll date after the effectiveness of his resignation and (ii) a </font><font style="display: inline;">$1.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million separation payment on the first anniversary of the effectiveness of his resignation. In accordance with </font><font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">ASC </font><font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">420</font><font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;"> &#x2013; Exit or Disposal Cost Obligations</font><font style="display: inline;">, &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">the Company will recognize first and second installment payments of </font><font style="display: inline;">$1.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$1.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million ratably from December 27, 2013 through April 30, 2014. If the separation date occurs prior to April 30, 2014 due to the appointment of a new CEO by the board of directors, the Company will consider the entire </font><font style="display: inline;">$2.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million incurred and will expense the remaining portion on that date. Mr. McCarvel will also be entitled to receive any amount earned pursuant to the Company&#x2019;s 2013 annual incentive program, in such form and at such time as is provided under the terms of such program.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Mr. McCarvel also agreed to continue in a consulting capacity with the Company at his regular salary through April 30, 2014 if his successor is appointed prior to such date. Subject to continued service, Mr. McCarvel will be entitled to continued vesting through April 30, 2014 of the unvested portion of his existing restricted stock and restricted stock unit awards. Pursuant to the separation agreement, unvested share awards that are expected to vest through April 30, 2014 amounted to </font><font style="display: inline;">58,840</font><font style="display: inline;"> shares. </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">Additionally, pursuant to the terms of the separation agreement, Mr. McCarvel forfeited </font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;">388,745</font><font style="display: inline;font-family:Times;"> share awards not expected to vest through April 30, 2014.</font><font style="display: inline;"> The separation payments are conditioned upon the effectiveness of Mr. McCarvel&#x2019;s release of claims in favor of the Company and his compliance with the non-competition, non-solicitation and confidentiality covenants contained in the separation agreement.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 1.27 0.32 1.46 0.68 0.50 -0.04 0.33 0.12 0.40 0.15 -0.76 1.24 0.31 1.44 0.68 0.49 -0.04 0.33 0.12 0.40 0.15 -0.76 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Earnings per Share</font><font style="display: inline;">&#x2014;Basic and diluted earnings per common share (&#x201C;EPS&#x201D;) is presented using the two-class method, which is an earnings allocation formula that determines earnings per share for common stock and any participating securities according to dividend rights and participation rights in undistributed earnings. Under the two-class method, EPS is computed by dividing the sum of distributed and undistributed earnings attributable to common stockholders by the weighted average number of shares of common stock outstanding during the period. A participating security is an unvested share-based payment award containing non-forfeitable rights to dividends and must be included in the computation of earnings per share pursuant to the two-class method. Shares of the Company&#x2019;s non-vested restricted stock awards are considered participating securities. Diluted EPS reflects the potential dilution from securities that could share in the earnings of the Company. Anti-dilutive securities are excluded from diluted EPS. See Note&nbsp;12&#x2014;Earnings per Share for further discussion.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">12. EARNINGS PER SHARE</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The following table illustrates the basic and diluted earnings per
